awd_abstract_narration:
Proteins are large molecules consisting of hundreds or thousands of amino acid residues forming a polymer with the amino acids arranged in a defined sequence. They are pivotal for all living organisms and of central importance for health care and biotechnology. Protein molecules exhibit distinct three- dimensional structural features governing their function. However, it is not entirely clear how the amino acid sequence determines structural features. In particular, this holds for the "hydrophobic effect" which arises because some amino acids with 'oil like properties' are quite insoluble in water. As a result, these residues tend to form an interior core of the protein molecule (alike a tiny oil droplet in water) to minimize exposure to the surrounding water. The incomplete understanding of the hydrophobic effect results from the enormous complexity of protein-water interactions. In turn, this prevents accurate prediction of structure and stability from sequence and accurate design of novel proteins. A primary potential benefit of this project will be a significant enhancement of the understanding of the hydrophobic effect. This will be accomplished by combining cutting-edge biophysics with computational protein design methodology in new and integrated protocols to enable more accurate protein structure prediction and engineering. All protocols and products of this project will be made publicly available. Excellent training of young scientists, in particular from underrepresented minorities, in protein biophysics and computational design, is a major goal of this project. Apart from highly individual mentoring of research and career development, annual summer schools will be held to reach communities outside of biophysical research and to increase interest in "STEM" in general.

It is a central conjecture of protein thermodynamics that the structured state of a protein as well as the loss of protein structure at very low temperatures ('cold denaturation') result from the hydrophobic effect. This project will focus on the engineering of cold denaturing proteins by iterating between computational design of protein structure and thermodynamic profile using the program Rosetta and biophysical characterization of the designs. The thermodynamic characterization will be pursued by use of circular dichroism (CD)-based Gibbs-Helmholtz analyses as well as differential scanning calorimetry (DSC), and the structural characterization of structured and denatured states by use of CD and nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) spectroscopy, and small angle X-ray scattering (SAXS). Such iterative protein engineering will test and improve in an unprecedented manner our understanding of protein thermodynamics and computational design methodology.

por.por_cntn:
Overview

Proteins are biological macromolecules which are linear heteropolymers formed by linking a large number of amino acids to form a chain. Proteins are crucial for life and are thus key targets for fundamental and biomedical research. Importantly, their function is linked to how the linear chain "folds", that is, how it adopts a defined three-dimensional structure. Our research contributed to enhance the understanding of the rules of protein folding as they specifically apply at low temperatures. This is required (i) to understand life in the vast ecosystems existing at low temperatues (in part well below the freezing point of water), (ii) to understand the role of low temperature protein states for protein function, diseases, vaccine development, and drug formulation, and (iii) to enhance the engineering of biomedically important cold adapted proteins, as well as the creation of new (supramolecular or nano)-materials. We established a unique approach by combining computational protein design and the experimental characterization of the designed proteins by a large variety of complementary biophysical techniques and molecular dynamics simulations. This enabled us to (i) create and study designed model proteins, (ii) to explore their structural and energetic features in order to robustly test related theories, and (iii) to improve computational design protocols as we employed them, for the first time, for the design of cold unfolding proteins.

Intellectual Merit

Counterintuitively, proteins tend to lose their defined three-dimensional structure (and thus possibly their function) at low temperatures, a phenomenon called "cold unfolding". This is a result of subtly balanced interactions within the folded protein molecule, between the protein molecule and water molecules and between the water molecules themselves. Experimental and computational research with our designed proteins yielded novel insights into these interactions, showing that the interaction of water molecules with protein core residues featuring a high affinity to water ("hydrophilic residues") play a decisive role in triggering cold unfolding when the temperature is lowered (to about the freezing point of water for our designs), and that several water molecules subsequently form clusters within a compact, only partially unfolded "cold state" in which the protein's substructures ("helices") remain intact. When lowering the temperature further, i.e., well below the freezing point of water, we observed that two protein molecules tend to stick together and form "dimers". Such complicated cold transitions cannot be predicted with existing theories and are in stark contrast to the unfolding at high temperatures where the protein chain adopts random conformations. We characterized the cold unfolding energetically and likewise discovered that our comprehensive knowledge regarding heat unfolding does not allow to rationalize the entirety of our findings. Our research thus enabled us to generate new, testable hypotheses to drive further the field of protein cold unfolding. These hypotheses are related (i) to understanding the cooperativity of cold unfolding based on the structure of a folded protein's core, (ii) to explaining the role of water leading to the discovered complexity of cold transitions, (iii) to understanding the evolutionary adaptation of proteins to function at low temperatures (specifically, for example, anti-freeze proteins allowing organisms to survive below the freezing point of water), and (iv) to delineating potential functional roles of cold protein states when lowly populated at ambient temperatures. Since we tested existing computational protein design protocols in an unprecedented manner, i.e. for the design of cold unfolding proteins, we were able to improve previously existing protocols and contributed to establishing theoretical and computational approaches to predict the nature of protein cold transitions.

Broader Impacts

Our project provided unique opportunities for research, teaching and mentoring in the field of protein science, specifically protein design and biophysics, for 17 scientists: five undergraduate students (all graduated), eight graduate students (all graduated with an M.Sc. or Ph.D.), and four senior post-doctoral researchers. In particular, 7 out of the 13 students (~50%) were from underrepresented minorities enabling the improvement of their skills that improved their access to or retention in research, teaching, or other related professions. To reinforce this goal and to increase interest of STEM in general, we (i) leveraged established, major initiatives at their schools which are dedicted to promote inclusive communities, to retain underrepresented students in STEM and to mentor students, (ii) actively participated in existing REUs, (iii) offered webinars on ?linchpins? for the understanding of (bio)physical chemistry and (bio)physics, and (iv) offered programming workshops focusing on methods for molecular modeling. Since our research activities tackles major challenges in biology and protein design, they benefit society by enhancing basic as well as translational biomedical and biotechnological research. We disseminated important outcomes by (i) publication in peer reviewed scientific journals, (ii) oral presentations and posters, (iii) deposition of protein structures and experimental parameters in publicly available databases, and (iv) we incorporated our new computational protocols into the widely used main repository of the ?Rosetta? protein design software package.
